Homage to these foremost innumerable, boundless, inexpressible Buddhas.
Homage to the sublime Dharma they expound, homage to their sublime Dharma-body, homage to their immeasurable, boundless merits of the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks.
I take refuge in the various Dharma wheels of those Buddhas that are irreversible.

The bodhisattvas, the great bhiká¹£us, the irreversible assembly of Å›rÄvakas, the bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, upÄsikÄs, devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as, kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, with various appearances, who have faith in the Dharma wheel of the TathÄgata;
The inconceivable bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who turn the Dharma wheel of the TathÄgata, I take refuge in them all.

I take refuge in the Dharma body of the TathÄgata, the ten powers, the four forms of fearlessness, the categories of precepts, concentration, and wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and insight of liberation. In such immeasurable and boundless merits, I dedicate such merits to all sentient beings, wishing that they may attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!
In the Good Eyes eon, there were seventy koá¹­Ä«s of buddhas who appeared in the world.
ÅšÄriputra!
In the Well Seen eon, there were 7.2 billion buddhas who appeared in the world.
ÅšÄriputra!
In the eon praised by BrahmÄ, there were 18,000 buddhas who appeared in the world.
ÅšÄriputra!
In the eon named Past, there were 32,000 buddhas who appeared in the world.
ÅšÄriputra!
In the Adorned eon, there were 84,000 buddhas who appeared in the world.
ÅšÄriputra!
You should take refuge in these immeasurable and boundless buddhas.
The Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:
Good sons and good women who wish to eliminate all offenses should bathe and put on new clean clothes. Reciting the names of these buddhas, making offerings and paying homage, they should say:

'From beginningless world systems until now, I have committed unwholesome actions with my body, speech, and mind, up to slandering the Vaipulya sÅ«tras and committing the five heinous crimes. May they all be extinguished.
ÅšÄriputra!

If good men and good women wish to fulfill the practice of the six perfections, wish to dedicate themselves to unsurpassed enlightenment, and wish to fulfill all the perfections of the bodhisattvas, they should say:

'I will learn from the past, future, and present bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, who practiced great renunciation, broke open their chests, and offered their hearts to sentient beings, like Bodhisattva JÃ±ÄnavÄ«rya and King KÄÅ›i.
They gave away their wives and children and so forth as alms to the poor, like Bodhisattva Avaivartika and King AÅ›Ä«raá¹‡a, SudÄna and King VibhÄ«á¹£aá¹‡a.
They entered the hells to save suffering sentient beings, like Bodhisattva MahÄkÄruá¹‡ika and Prince Sunetra.
They saved sentient beings of evil conduct, like Bodhisattva Suciká¹›tya and King ViÅ›iá¹£á¹­acÄritra.
They gave away the precious heavenly crown on top of their heads and even their scalp, like Bodhisattva ViÅ›iá¹£á¹­aÅ›arÄ«ra and Prince RatnacÅ«á¸a.

Giving away eyes, like the bodhisattvas Beloved-to-Make and Moon-Light King and others.ğŸ”½Giving away ears and nose, like the bodhisattva No-Enemy and the celestial prince Victorious-Departure and others.
Giving away teeth, like the bodhisattva Flower-Teeth and the six-tusked elephant king and others.
Giving away tongues, like the bodhisattva Non-Retrogression and the king Good-Face and others.
Giving away hands, like the bodhisattva Always-Vigorous and the king Firm-Intent and others.
Giving away blood, like the bodhisattva Dharma-Maker and the celestial prince Moon-Thought and others.
Giving away flesh and marrow, like the bodhisattva Peace-and-Security and the king Universal-Alms and others.
Giving away large and small intestines, liver, lungs, spleen, and kidneys, like the bodhisattva Good-Virtue and the king who has distanced himself from all evil and others.
Giving away the entire body, large and small limbs and joints, like the bodhisattva Dharma-Sovereign and the celestial prince Light-Superior and others.
Giving away skin, like the bodhisattva Pure-Store and the celestial prince Golden-Color and the golden deer king and others.
Giving up fingers and toes, like the Bodhisattva Firm Effort and King Golden Color, and so forth.
Giving up fingernails and toenails, like the Bodhisattva Inexhaustible and the Heavenly Son Seeking the Good Dharma, and so forth.
For the sake of seeking the Dharma, entering a great fiery pit, like the Bodhisattva Diligent Effort and King Diligent Effort Seeking Sand, and so forth.

For the sake of seeking the Dharma, selling one's body, cutting open one's body, breaking one's bones, and extracting one's marrow, like the Bodhisattva SadÄprarudita and King Golden Strength, and so forth.
Enduring all suffering and distress, like the Bodhisattva Seeking Wonderful Dharma and the Great King Swift Action, and so forth.
Giving up the four continents, the great earth, and all adornments, like the Bodhisattva MahÄsthÄmaprÄpta and the Heavenly Son Excellent Merit, and so forth.
Giving up one's body, like the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva and King MahÄbala, and so forth.
With one's own body, acting as a servant and attendant for all poor and suffering beings, like King Åšibi, and so forth.
In brief, may I also accomplish all the perfections practiced by the bodhisattvas of the past, present, and future;

The wonderful incense, flowers, garlands, and music of the worlds of the ten directions, I rejoice in making offerings to the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, and further dedicate this merit to all sentient beings.
May, due to this merit, sentient beings not fall into evil destinies.

Due to this merit, may they perfect the eighty-four thousand perfections, quickly receive the prediction of supreme perfect enlightenment, quickly attain the stage of nonretrogression, and quickly accomplish supreme enlightenment.

Respectfully bow to the great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas in the ten directions.

Homage to the Bodhisattva Heavenly King. I take refuge in the immeasurable and boundless great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas of the ten directions and three times.
I respectfully pay homage to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all sages.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I will next repent.
Disciples!
Next, I repent of the karma of robbery and theft.
The sÅ«tras say:
If an object belongs to someone else and is guarded by them, not even a blade of grass or a leaf should be taken without permission, let alone steal it.
However, sentient beings only see the benefits in the present, so they take things through various improper means, causing them to receive these calamities in the future.
Therefore, the sÅ«tras say:
The crime of robbery and theft can cause sentient beings to fall into the hells and hungry ghost realms to suffer.
If in the animal realm, they will take on the form of cows, horses, donkeys, mules, camels, and so forth, using their own physical strength and blood and flesh to repay past debts.

If reborn among humans, they become slaves to others, their clothes do not cover their bodies, and their food does not fill their stomachs. They are poor, cold, and miserable, with little human dignity.
Since stealing has such painful consequences, disciples!
Today, I bow my head in surrender and take refuge in the Buddha.

Homage to the Buddha of Great Wisdom in the East, Homage to the Buddha of the Great Assembly in the South, Homage to the Buddha of Pure Wisdom in the West, Homage to the Buddha of Wisdom and Renown in the North, Homage to the Buddha of the King of Upholding Precepts in the Southeast, Homage to the Buddha of Increasing Good Dharmas in the Southwest, Homage to the Buddha of Well-Released Incense in the Northwest, Homage to the Buddha of the King of Pure Space in the Northeast, Homage to the Buddha of Lions in the Nadir, Homage to the Buddha of Counteracting Empty Light in the Zenith. I take refuge in the Three Jewels in the ten directions and throughout space.
Disciples!

From beginningless time until today, we may have stolen others' wealth and valuables, wielding weapons to rob forcefully, or relying on our own power and status to take by coercion, or relying on official authority or power, using heavy penalties and large shackles to oppress the innocent, taking bribes, torturing to extract confessions, twisting the truth, or using these causes and conditions to entangle ourselves in legal nets.

We may have served as biased judges, taking others' wealth, encroaching on public goods for private gain, encroaching on private goods for public gain, harming others for our own benefit, benefiting others to harm ourselves, taking from others to enrich ourselves, giving with our mouths while begrudging in our hearts.
We may have secretly evaded taxes and duties, smuggled goods across borders, concealed public taxes, or hidden goods to avoid paying taxes.
We have committed such offenses, immeasurable and boundless, and today we feel ashamed and take refuge in repentance.

Either taking what is not given belonging to the Buddha, Dharma, or Sangha, or taking the property of scriptures and images, or the property of repairing stupas and temples, or the property of the permanent monastic community, or the property of the visiting monastic community, or taking by theft or using in error without returning out of reliance on power, or borrowing oneself or lending to others, or exchanging, borrowing, leaking, or falsely claiming, or mixing and using the property of the Three Jewels in a chaotic manner, or using the property of the monastic community such as grain, firewood, ginger, bean sauce, vinegar, vegetables, fruits, money, silk, bamboo, wood, silk banners, canopies, incense, flowers, and oil lamps according to one's emotions and desires.

It is possible to deceive and not give the property donated to the Three Jewels, either using it oneself or giving it to others, or plucking the flowers of the Buddha, using the property of the monastic community, or privately benefiting oneself through the wealth of the Three Jewels.
Sins such as these are immeasurable and boundless, and today I am ashamed and repent in confession.
Moreover, disciples!
From beginningless time until today, we have been friends, teachers, colleagues, parents, siblings, and relatives, living together in a hundred and one ways, deceiving each other.

In the neighborhood, we have moved fences and expanded walls, encroaching on land and houses, changing boundaries and seizing fields and gardens, taking over shops and fields under the pretext of public or private matters.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. We now confess and repent before the Three Jewels.
Furthermore, disciples!
From beginningless time until today, we have attacked cities and villages, burned villages and destroyed barriers, stolen and sold good people, and enticed others' slaves and servants.

We have also oppressed innocent people, causing them to be mutilated, wounded, and imprisoned, destroying their families and businesses, separating their bones and flesh, dispersing them to different cities, and cutting off their lives.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. We now confess and repent with shame.
Moreover, disciples,

from beginningless time until today, we have engaged in commerce, bartered goods, set up shops and stalls, and engaged in trade, using light scales and small measures, cutting corners and reducing sizes, stealing even the smallest amounts, deceiving with the smallest units of weight or volume, exchanging inferior goods for superior ones, and using short lengths for longer ones, with hundreds of deceptive tricks hoping for the slightest profit.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless, and today we are ashamed and take refuge in repentance.
Moreover, disciples,
from beginningless time until today, we have breached walls and barriers, cut off roads and plundered, resisted paying debts and interest, defaulted on loans and deceived people to their faces.

We have violated the paths of ghosts, spirits, birds, and beasts, and taken the belongings of the four types of living beings, or pretended to divine and predict to obtain people's wealth and treasures, and even used profits to seek more profits, seeking evil and much, with no contentment or satisfaction.
Such offenses are immeasurable, boundless, and cannot be fully described. Today, I sincerely repent before the Buddhas, the Venerable Dharma, and the Holy Sangha in the ten directions.

May the disciples, by repenting of the offenses of stealing and so forth, and the merit generated, wish to be born in every life with a wish-fulfilling jewel, always raining down the seven treasures, the finest garments, the hundred flavors of nectar, and various medicinal soups and tonics, all according to one's needs, arriving upon command. May all beings be free from the act of stealing, all be able to have few desires and be content, not indulging or being attached, always enjoying generosity and practicing the way of immediate relief, giving away one's head, eyes, marrow, and brain like discarded mucus and saliva, dedicating this to the perfection of generosity.
The Sutra of the Monk Baodai's Questions and Answers on the Retribution of Karmic Causes in the Lotus Treasury, Part 1: Baodai then entered the Meigeng Jiaoquan Hell.
In that hell, the fierce fire was blazing, with smoke and flames rising together, and the sinful beings entered it to suffer myriad hardships.
In the west gate, there were some monks who came in, moaning and causing the earth to shake.
The horse-headed rakshasa held an iron hammer and struck their heads. The sinners screamed and ran, and the yakshas chased after them and beat them.

They had nowhere to hide, and ran to the east gate, which was closed. The south, north, and west gates were also like this. For a day and night, they suffered painful retribution, unable to live or die.
Baota asked the horse-headed rakshasa:
What sins did these monks commit to receive such retribution?
The horse-headed rakshasa replied:
These monks received the Buddha's pure precepts but had no compassionate thoughts. They beat animals with sticks and had no compassion. For this reason, they received such punishment.
When Baota heard this, he wept and left.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
